Anhui Province Key Laboratory of Low Temperature Co-Fired Materials School of Chemistry and Materials Engineering Huainan Normal University Huainan 232038 China The conversion of biomass-based compounds into highly value-added chemicals has received extensive attention in recent years. This work reports the liquid-phase selective hydrogenation and furan ring-rearrangement of furfural (FFL) into cyclopentanone (CPO) and cyclopentanol (CPL) over Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalysts and water as the solvent. The specific reaction rate of the optimal catalyst at 160 °C reaches 538 h–1, and the selectivity of CPO/CPL is 77.5 %. By adopting the ion-exchange and formamide treatment methods, the type of the interlayer anions and interlayer spacing for the CoAl-HTs supports can be regulated, which can affect the state of the supported Pd sites and their catalytic activity and selectivity towards the ring-rearrangement products. Furthermore, the H2/D2 exchange experimental results demonstrate that the presence of the interlayer NO3 – anions of CoAl-HTs support promotes the activation and dissociation of H2, thereby accelerating the hydrogenation of FFL to cyclic compounds. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective hydrogenation Ring rearrangement Furfural Pd catalyst Hydrotalcites Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction The exploitation and utilization of renewable resources is an effective measure to solve the energy crisis and environmental problem [1–3]. Biomass, a kind of important carbon-neutral material, can be employed for refining high value-added fine chemicals [4–6]. Furfural (FFL), which is mainly produced by hemicellulose dehydration, serves as one of representative biomass-based platform compounds with great development potential, and therefore its catalytic upgrading process has received extensive attention from researchers in recent years [7–9]. The transformation process of FFL can be realized by thermos-catalysis, photo-catalysis and electro-catalysis processes or their coupled processes [10–13]. Hydrogenation reaction network of FFL into various products is illustrated in Scheme 1 . One-step hydrogenation of FFL can produce furfuryl alcohol (FA). Further hydrogenation of FA leads to production of tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA), whereas hydrogenative furan ring-opening and rearrangement select the formation of cyclic compounds such as cyclopentanone (CPO) and cyclopentanol (CPL), which possesses relatively high economic value for producing critical intermediates of pharmaceuticals, dyes and fragrances [14]. As reported by the literatures, the important factors including catalyst, solvent, temperature, hydrogen pressure, etc., can affect the hydrogenation activity and selectivity of FFL [15]. Specifically, to achieve a high selectivity to the ring-rearranged products (CPO and CPL) presents more challenges than controlling hydrogenation selectivity to produce FA since complex factors should be considered with respect to multiple active sites, parallel reaction pathways, solvent-involvement [16–22]. For instance, by combining the catalytic tests and isotope experiments, the mechanism of FFL to CPO and CPL over Pd/C catalyst has been elucidated as: (1) FFL hydrogenation to FA; (2) FA rearrangement to 4‐hydroxy‐2‐cyclopentenone (HCP); (3) HCP dehydration and hydrogenation to CPO and (4) CPO further hydrogenation to CPL [23]. It is still necessary to deeply explore the structure-activity relationship as well as to well tune the structure of the metal catalysts for promoting the catalytic performance towards selective hydrogenation and rearrangement of FFL. Considerable efforts have been made to develop the metal-based FFL hydrogenation catalysts in terms of regulating the properties of metal sites and supports such as reductive metal oxides, zeolites, carbon materials and metal-organic framework compounds (MOF) materials [24–32]. Furthermore, it has also been clarified that the presence of the additive Brønsted acid or Lewis acid species or sites can play a synergistic effect with metal site to catalyze FFL hydrogenation and rearrangement. For instance, the Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface and the added nitrate and chloride salts have been demonstrated to boost the catalytic activity and selectivity in Pd@Na-ZSM-5- and Ni/SiC-catalyzed FFL hydrogenation [33,34]. As an important solvent and cocatalyst, water not only provides a medium environment, but also participates as a hydrogen source in the hydrogenative rearrangement process. Cai et al. confirmed by kinetic and isotopic experiments that Ni/Nb2O5 catalyst can hydrogenate FFL to CPO with a yield of more than 92 %, mainly because the aqueous solvent not only promotes FFL activation but also assists the transfer of hydrogen species under the interaction of metal support [35]. The synergistic interaction of water as a solvent and solid acids plays a positive role in the production of the cyclic compounds [35–37]. Therefore, the acid- or water-involved reaction microenvironment significantly determines the comprehensive catalytic property, which is worth further investigation. Based on this view, hydrotalcites (HTs) with adjustable acid-base sites, layer space and interlayer species, can serve as the ideal supports of metallic catalysts to explore the effect of microenvironment in FFL hydrogenation reaction. HTs have a typical two-dimensional sheet structure, and its unique ion exchange capacity, surface adsorption ability and surface acid-base adjustment have attracted widespread attention in the field of catalysis [38–41]. Generally, different anion-intercalated HTs possess different interactions between the laminates and exchanging anions as well as the varied hydration degree of HTs [42]. The highly charged anions are easily intercalated into the galley of HTs than low-charge anions, for instance, the interlayer anion exchange sequence of PO 4 3 − > CO 3 2 − > Cl– > NO 3 − , depending on the Gibbs free energy that occurs in the anion exchange reaction and the ability to form hydrogen bond between the interlayer anions and hydroxyl groups [38]. Therefore, one of the effective strategies to achieve anion exchange of HTs is the intercalation using formamide. As a highly polar solvent, formamide can form a strong hydrogen bond with the hydroxyl group of HTs laminates via the C=O group and form a weak hydrogen bond with interlayer anions and water via the amine group, inhibiting the growth of the Z-axis of HTs and destroying the layered structure for thus promoting the anion change [43,44]. In this work, we synthesized CoAl-HTs supports with different Co/Al ratios and interlayer anions by hydrothermal method and post-treatment such as the intercalation with formamide, and prepared Pd/CoAl-HTs catalysts by NaBH4 reduction. We evaluated the effects of the catalyst structure in terms of Co/Al ratio and interlayer anion species (i.e., CO3 2– and NO3 –) on the catalytic performance in FFL hydrogenative rearrangement into cyclic compounds. The effects of reaction temperature, pressure and solvent have also been investigated. H2/D2 exchange experiments were performed to further explore the H2 activation and dissociation ability. Experimental Chemicals and gasses Furfural was purchased by from Tokyo Chemical Industry (Shanghai), Sodium tetrachloropalladate (NaPdCl4), cyclopentanone (CPO), cyclopentanol (CPL), Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), Aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O), urea, ethyl acetate (EA), isopropyl alcohol (i-PrOH) were achieved by Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Sodium borohydride (NaBH4) and cyclohexane (C6H12) were obtained from Sinopharm Group Reagent Co., Ltd. Hydrogen (H2), nitrogen (N2), and 15 vol.% H2/Ar were required by Nanjing Special Gas Company. Deuterium gas (D2) was gained from Suzhou Changyou Gas Co., Ltd. Catalyst preparation CoAl-HTs-CO3 with interlayer CO3 2– anion and different molar ratios of Co:Al (1:2, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1) were prepared using hydrothermal method [41]. Certain amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O and urea were dissolved in 120 mL deionized water. Stirring vigorously for 20 min at room temperature to obtain a clear and transparent solution. The mixed salt solution was introduced to 200 mL autoclave and placed in a 150 ℃ oven for 12 h. The solid sample was filtered, washed with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol to remove the remaining impurities in the solution, and then dried at 70 ℃ overnight for obtaining the CoAl-HTs-CO3 sample as pink powder. CoAl-HTs-NO3 with interlayer NO3 – anion was synthesized from the as-prepared CoAl-HTs-CO3 by salt-acid mixed solution treatment. 1.0 g sample was dispersed into 1 L mixed solution of 1 M NaNO3 and 3.3 mM HNO3. The mixture was stirred for 48 h in N2 atmosphere, centrifugated, washed and dried to obtain the anion-exchanged CoAl-HTs-NO3 support. 0.5 g CoAl-HTs-NO3 sample was scattered to 500 mL formamide, and stirred for 48 h at room temperature in N2. The pink colloidal suspension was centrifugated at 8000 rpm for 3 min to obtain CoAl-HTs-NO3-EM. All Pd/CoAl-HTs catalysts with 1 wt.% Pd loading were prepared by NaBH4 reduction method. Typically, 0.5 g CoAl-HTs support was introduced into 10 mL NaPdCl4 solutions for 2 h. The molar amount of NaBH4 reductant is 8 times higher than that of Pd. The mixture was stirred for 2 h and dried to obtain the supported Pd catalyst. Catalytic hydrogenation reaction The selective hydrogenation of FFL to open-ring rearrangement compounds was operated in 50 mL stainless steel autoclave with PTEE container (NSC50-P5-T3-SS1-SV-R, Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd). In a typical operation, 200 μL FFL, 20 mg catalyst, and 10 mL water were introduced into a 50 mL reactor. After purging with H2 several times to remove the residual air. The reaction was manipulated with 30 bar H2 under the given condition with a stirring speed of 700 rpm for eliminating the mass transfer limitation. The reactor was cooled to room temperature in ice-water bath after the reaction. The reaction solution was treated with ethyl acetate and centrifuged to achieve solid-liquid separation. The reactants and products were analyzed by a gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and CP-WAX 52 CB column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). The separated catalyst was filtrated, washed with ethanol and dried at 70 ℃ for the catalytic cycle testing. The following formulas were used to calculate the conversion of FFL, specific reaction rate and the selectivity of products. FFL conversion ( % ) = [ n FFL ( initial ) − n FFL ( final ) ] / n FFL ( initial ) × 100 % Product selectivity ( % ) = [ n Product B ( final ) / n total product ( final ) ] × 100 % Specific reaction rate ( h − 1 ) = [ conversion × n FFL ( initial ) ] / [ time × N surface ( Pd ) ] Where n represents the molar amount of reactant or product; product B represents a certain product; Nsurface(Pd) is the molar number of surface Pd atoms in employed catalyst. Catalyst characterizations The crystal phase structure of all catalysts was analyzed by X-ray diffractometer (XRD, DX-2800, Haoyuan Instrument Co., Ltd.), and Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) was used at a voltage of 40 kV, a current of 30 mA, a step size of 0.4°, and a scanning range of 5–90° in 2θ. The chemical state of element was provided by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Kalpha) with an Al-Kα radiation excitation source. The BET surface area and pore volume of the catalyst were supplied by N2 adsorption/desorption measurement collected on a Micromeritics APSP 2460 at –196 ℃. All catalysts were degassed at 150 ℃ for 6 h before the test. The topography and elemental distribution of catalysts were provided by the transmission electron microscope (TEM, Gemini300) equipped with field emission. The size of Pd nanoparticles (NPs) was calculated according to the TEM images. The ultraviolet–visible diffuse reflectance (UV–Vis-DR) spectra were analyzed by Lambda 950 spectrometer with integrating sphere (PerkinElmer) from 250 to 900 nm. Thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using the thermos analysis system (Mettler Toledo TGA 2) in 50 mL/min of air with a rising rate of 10 °C/min. The functional group types of the sample were detected by the Fourier transform infrared spectrum (FT-IR, Nicolet iS10 spectrometer) produced by Thermo Scientific. The dry mixture of 2 mg sample and 98 mg KBr was pressed to a pellet. The scanning was collected for 16 times in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 with a resolution of 4 cm–1. Fourier transform infrared spectra of pyridine adsorption (FT-IR-Py) were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer with DigiTect TM detector. The catalysts were pressed into tablets and pretreated at 150 ℃ for 1 h. After cooling down to 25 °C, pyridine was adsorbed for 0.5 h. When the residual pyridine was eliminated, the desorption spectra were collected at certain temperatures. H2-D2 exchange experiments were operated in a fixed bed, and the reactor was equipped with 6 mm quartz tube. The 20 mg catalyst was introduced to the tube, and the as-prepared sample was pretreated in N2 at 150 ℃ for 1 h. The mixed gas containing H2, D2, N2 with a volume ratio of 1:1:3 was introduced to the reactor when the reaction temperature cooled down to 80 ℃. The signal of H2, D2 and HD were recorded by an online mass spectrometer (MS, Hiden QGA). Results and discussion Physical and chemical property of Pd-based catalysts CoxAly-HTs-CO3 supports with carbonate intercalated anions and different Co/Al ratios (x:y = 1:2, 2:1, 3:1 and 4:1) were prepared through hydrothermal procedure. Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 was synthesized by ion-exchange method. With these supports, the supported Pd/CoAl-HTs catalysts with 1 % Pd loading amounts were prepared via NaBH4 reduction method, and the structural property was characterized in this section. The full range FT-IR spectra of all samples are shown in Fig. 1 a. The strong peak at 3430 cm–1 is assigned to the vibration of O–H bands of CoAl-HTs. The peak at 1560 cm–1 is associated with the vibration of interlayer water species. The vibration bands at around 550, 614 and 793 cm–1 are derived from Co–O and Al–O groups [45–48]. The peak situated at 1359–1356 cm–1 is attributed to the stretching of CO3 2– interlayer anions for all different Co/Al ratios HTs supports. As a contrast, a shifted peak is presented at about 1384 cm–1 for Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 and Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM supports, and no formamide was detected on the surface of the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 1b, which is caused by the NO3 – interlayer anions [49,50]. These spectral results indicate that the interlaminar CO3 2– anions of CoAl-HTs-CO3 can be effectively replaced by NO3 – anions through the post-exchange procedure and the later anions are stable against the subsequent formamide treatment [42]. The FT-IR results also showed that the CO3 2– anions could be completely replaced by NO3 – anions in the exchange process, although CO3 2– anions and the HTs layer have a strong affinity for the formation of hydrogen bonds, especially for the HTs synthesized by urea decomposition method, which contained more CO3 2– anions that are generally difficult to be exchanged [49,50]. The Pd loading is maintained at 1.0 ± 0.2 wt.% provided by the ICP-OES analysis results for all these Pd/CoAl-HTs catalysts, as summarized in Table 1 . The XRD patterns of all Pd-based catalysts supported in CoAl-HTs are shown in the range of 5–90°, as shown in Fig. 2 . For a series of Pd/CoxAly-HTs-CO3 catalysts, the typical diffraction peaks located at 2θ=11.7° and 23.9° are corresponding to (003) and (006) plane of CoAl-HT phase, respectively. The sharp and symmetrical peaks imply that the layer structure of CoAl-HTs can be well maintained after the deposition of Pd nanoparticles on the support surfaces. The interlayer space values for the CoAl-HTs are about 7.5 Å as deferred to Braggs law, as listed in Table 1. For Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 catalyst, the diffraction peaks of CoAl-HTs phase reveal slightly shifted center position and broad width. Specifically, its interlayer space is increased to 7.8 Å, respectively (Table 1), which is mainly attributed to a lower affinity of CoAl-HTs layers with NO3 – anions than with CO3 2– anions [42]. For Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalyst, the interlayer space of CoAl-HTs is 7.4 Å, suggesting that CO3 2– anions are introduced to the Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 and Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM support in the process of loading metal Pd nanoparticles [51,52]. In addition, the diffraction peak of Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalyst is obviously weak, indicating that the Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 crystals densely stacked by the hydrogen bond network were delaminated after formamide treatment. Once the interlayer water molecule is replaced by formamide, the interaction between the laminates will be weakened for causing the collapse and deformation of the crystal structure of HTs [44,53]. It is not negligible that Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM is restacked during the preparation of Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalyst and its HT layer space is reduced by 0.4 Å. This may indicate that HTs nanosheets after formamide treatment are unstable in water medium [54]. Furthermore, neither Pd- nor PdO-related diffraction peaks is present, illustrating that Pd NPs may be highly dispersed with small particle size. The TGA measurements of Co4Al1-HTs support and Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalyst were also performed. As shown in Fig. S1, the TGA curves of these two samples show similar weight-loss patterns and the contents of water and interlayer CO3 2– anions are estimated as 28 %. This result confirms the structural stability of the interlayer water and CO3 2– species of Co4Al1-HTs support against the introduction of Pd species. The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms are shown in Fig. S2, providing the pore volume and surface area for CoAl-HTs support and all Pd-based catalysts. Pd/Co1Al2-HTs-CO3 exhibits the maximum surface area and pore volume (47 m2 g–1 and 0.29 cm3 g–1, respectively, Table 1). For Pd/CoAl-HTs with other Co/Al ratios, the surface area is ca. 14 m2 g–1 and the pore volume remain around 0.08 cm3 g–1. Due to the change of interlayer anions, lower surface area and pore volume are observed on Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 catalyst. For Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalyst, the layered structure collapses, and more nanosheets gather randomly after formamide exfoliation [48,55]. It causes increased surface area (31 m2 g–1) and pore volume (0.11 cm3 g–1). The TEM images afford the morphology of Pd/CoAl-HTs catalysts and their size distribution of Pd NPs on supports. All Pd/CoAl-HTs catalysts display similar nanosheet-like structure regardless of Co/Al ratio and interlayer anion (CO3 2– or NO3 –), as illustrated in Fig. 3 a–f. Especially, some irregular and small-size fragments were formed due to the fracture and breakage of Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 in the formamide treatment process [44]. The Pd NPs are highly dispersed on the surface of CoAl-HTs supports. The mean sizes (dn) and the surface sizes (ds) of Pd NPs decrease with increasing of Co/Al ratio (1/2 to 4/1) for all Pd/CoAl-HTs-CO3 catalysts. The dn and ds sizes of Pd NPs for Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 catalyst are 3.11 and 3.57 nm, respectively. The dispersion of Pd is 28.0 % and 22 % for Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 and Pd/Co1Al2-HTs-CO3 catalyst, respectively, which depends on the distinct interactions between Pd active metal and CoAl-HTs support, as listed in Fig. 3g–j and Table 1. The dispersion of Pd over the surface of CoAl-HTs support is enhanced when the Co/Al ratios was increased from 1/2 to 4/1. For Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 and Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalysts, the size of Pd NPs is slightly increased to 4.51±1.43 and 4.49±1.32 nm, as shown in Fig. 3k–l. Such decreased dispersion degree of Pd suggests that the interlayer anion exchange and exfoliation treatment can lead to vary the interaction between Pd NPs and CoAl-HTs support [52,56]. The UV–Vis-DR spectra in Fig. S3 illustrate that the Co2+ cations dominate over the Co species of CoAl-HTs in Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3, Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 and Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalysts. The bands at 457, 489, 521 and 625 nm are ascribed to the d-d transition of the Co2+ in CoAl-HTs, while the weak band at 380 nm is on account of O2–→Co2+ [41,57]. The XPS spectra was also employed to explore the chemical state of Pd species on surface of all Pd/CoAl-HTs. The results of peak splitting and fitting of Pd 3d XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 4 a. The Pd species include Pd0 and Pd2+ states. The peaks at 335.5 and 340.8 eV are ascribed into the binding energy of the spin-orbital splitting of metallic Pd0, while peaks located at 342.5 and 337.2 eV are attached to the 3d 3/2 and 3d 5/2 of Pd2+ state, respectively [52,56,58]. The calculated ratio of Pd2+/Pd0 in the Pd catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . The values are 27.6/72.4, 24.8/75.2, 31.8/68.2, 26.6/73.4 for Pd/Co1Al2-HTs-CO3, Pd/Co2Al1-HTs-CO3, Pd/Co3Al1-HTs-CO3 and Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3, respectively. The XPS spectral results also supply the distribution of Pd species for Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 and Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalysts, and the corresponding Pd2+/Pd0 ratio values are 44.8/55.2 and 24.5/75.4, respectively. The variation in the Pd2+/Pd0 ratio are attributed to the electron transfer between active metal Pd and CoAl-HTs. The co-existence of oxidative Co2+ and Co3+ species can be confirmed by XPS measurement in Fig. 4b. The binding energy at 797.1∼797.4 eV and 781.1∼783.3 eV is corresponding to Co2+, while that at 798.6∼798.8 eV and 783.1∼783.2 eV is corresponding to Co3+ [21,24]. Meanwhile, the ratios of Co2+/Co3+ are 3.42, 2.35, 3.49 and 3.16 in the Pd/CoAl-HTs-CO3 catalysts with different Co/Al ratios. Furthermore, the metal-support interaction could also be enhanced by the change of interlayer anion from CO3 2– to NO3 – in CoAl-HTs supports [52]. The acidic type of the catalyst surface is classified by employing FT-IR spectra of pyridine adsorption-desorption. The pyridine vapor was introduced into the cell for 30 min at room temperature after sample pretreatment. The desorption spectra of pyridine at 150 and 300 ℃ were recorded in the wavenumber range of 1400–1700 cm–1. As presented in Fig. 5 , the peak at 1596 cm–1 is due to the adsorption of pyridine on the H-donor sites [59]. The bands at 1643 and 1540 cm–1 are ascribed to the absorption of pyridine on the Brønsted acid sites [28]. The characterization peaks at 1619, 1490 and 1444 cm–1 are attributed to the adsorption of pyridine on the Lewis acid sites [24,59]. The total amount of Brønsted acid sites is 3.78 and 2.51 µmol/g, while the amount of high-strength Lewis acid sites is 46.22 and 25.93 µmol/g for Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 catalyst, respectively, indicating the presence of the strong Lewis acid sites on these catalysts. To sum up, all Pd-based catalysts have a layered structure. The regulation of Co/Al ratio can alter the specific area, pore volume and metal Pd particle size and distribution for Pd/CoAl-HTs catalysts. The interlayer anion and spaces are changed by anion exchange method and formamide exfoliation. The interlayer space of Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 support increased by 1.31 Å when the interlayer anion of Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 is exchanged with NO3 – anion. The formamide exfoliation causes layer structure of Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 to collapse, forming more nanosheet structures, which greatly increase the surface area for the Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalyst. The post-treatment of the Co4Al1-HTs will cause some Pd metal nanoparticle to enter the interlayer galleries of Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 and Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM. Obviously, the metal-support interface sites are further varied through the NaBH4 reduction process. Hydrogenation and ring-rearrangement of furfural The hydrogenation and ring-rearrangement of FFL was explored over the Pd/CoAl-HTs-CO3 catalysts by using water as reaction medium at 160 °C and 30 bar H2. It should be noted that the bare CoAl-HTs supports are almost inactive towards the reaction. FA, THFA, CPO and CPL are detected as the main products, and different product distributions are observed on the Pd/CoAl-HTs-CO3 catalysts with adjustable Co/Al ratios (0.5–4). As shown in Fig. 6 a, the catalytic results of all Pd/CoAl-HTs is subject to the Co/Al ratios. For the specific reaction rate, similar level is achieved on Pd/CoAl-HTs-CO3 catalysts. With decreasing Co/Al ratio from 4/1 to 1/2, the rate is enhanced from 523 to 578 h–1. With respect to the selectivity, Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalyst exhibits 59.5 % CPO selectivity and 18.0 % CPL selectivity. As contrast, the total selectivities of these two cyclic compounds over Pd/CoAl-HTs-CO3 catalysts with other Co/Al ratios are relatively lower, which are 49.5, 70.3 and 73.7 %. It is worth noting that the formation of FA is a crucial intermediate for hydrogenative rearrangement of FFL to cyclic compounds, mainly because the hydroxyl group on the hydrotalcite structure prevents the adsorption of C=C bonds on the furan ring due to electrostatic interaction, while the hydrophilicity of hydrotalcite is conducive to the adsorption of C=O bonds, thereby promoting the FA formation [60,61]. On the other hand, the formed FA also serves as the intermediate in the hydrogenation of furan ring to generate THFA by-product [62,63]. The result indicates that the selective production of cyclic-compound depends on the surface properties of these catalysts, and the performance of Pd-catalyzed FFL hydrogenation is enhanced via suitable Pd particle sizes. The catalytic performance of Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalyst was further studied at different reaction temperature, as shown in Fig. 6b. The specific reaction rate is increased from 295.2 to 622.9 h–1 with increasing temperature from 100 to 180 ℃. The FA with more than 90 % selectivity is the capital hydrogenation product at 100 and 120 ℃. When the reaction temperature is further increased to 140 ℃, the ring-arrangement products of CPO and CPL are produced along with the FA formation, and the selectivity of cyclic compounds and FA is 6.5 % and 88.5 %, respectively. When the reaction temperature reaches 160 ℃, the selectivity of cyclic compounds is promoted to 77.5 % while that of FA is reduced to 8.2 %. At a high reaction temperature of 180 ℃, the selectivity of CPO and CPL is 26.7 % and 61.2 %, respectively, and the total selectivity of ring-opening compounds is 87.9 %. The product distribution over Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalyst as a function of pressures of H2 is presented in Fig. 6c. The specific reaction rate increases with the H2 pressure in the range of 10–40 bar. The total selectivity of cyclic compounds, CPO and CPL, is 77.4 % when the H2 pressure exceeds 30 bar. Under the H2 pressure at 10 and 20 bar, the specific reaction rate of FFL is 141.8 and 538.7 h–1, while THFA and FA are the main hydrogenation product, respectively. At 40 bar H2, the selectivity of CPO is almost unchanged and the selectivity of CPL product increases to 23.1 %. It shows that H2 pressure of 30 bar is suitable to ensure that there is enough hydrogen source for hydrogenative rearrangement of FFL to cyclic compounds. The catalytic hydrogenation performance of FFL on Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 catalyst was evaluated in water as the solvent at 160 °C and 30 bar H2. The distribution of product as the time change is given in Fig. 6d. The FFL conversion is gradually increased and the product distribution is varied with the reaction time-on-stream. Within the initial reaction stage less than 1 h, FA with 85% selectivity is dominated in the products. As prolonged the reaction time, the formed FA gradually converts into ring-opening compounds until its complete conversion. At high FFL conversion of 98 % in 4 h, high selectivity of cyclic compounds reaches 85.2 %. This suggests that FA is an important intermediate for the hydrogenation and rearrangement of FFL into cyclic compounds [17,28,64]. In addition, CPO can be further hydrogenated to CPL at the high-FFL-conversion stage. Only small amount of by-product THFA is produced by over-hydrogenation of FA, indicating that Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 catalyst is capable of anti-hydrogenation of furan ring of FA to produce THFA and prefers ring-rearrangement. By contrasting with the reported Pd-based catalysts in FFL hydrogenation, as summarized in Table S1, 1 % Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 catalyst shows a comparable catalytic performance in terms of intrinsic activity and cyclic compounds selectivity. According to the previous research, the acid property of the catalyst is a crucial factor that influences the selectivity of cyclic compounds [28,35]. The surface of Co-based HTs presented the different Brønsted acidic sites and Lewis acidic sites with the increase of Co/Al ratios. The existence of Al in CoAl-HTs support increased a large amount of surface Brønsted acidic sites in the form of a bridge hydroxyl group in the Co–(OH)–Al unit or Al(OH)x species [39,65–67]. However, the presence of Al also generates more weak Lewis acid sites, and the amount of Lewis acid sites is significantly higher than that of Brønsted acid sites [19]. Based on the dual active site of Pd/CoAl-HTs catalysts consisted of Pd metal sites and surface acidic/basic site of CoAl-HTs support, structure-activity relationship is further discussed for hydrogenative rearrangement of FFL to cyclic compounds. CoOx species as Lewis acid site in the Pd/CoAl-HTs catalyst can adsorb oxygen-containing groups (C=O, C–O–C and O–H bond). By combining the effect of electron repulsion of hydroxyl groups of CoAl-HTs support, the adsorption of C=O bond is conductive to subsequent ring-opening rearrangement. Simultaneously, the highly dispersed Pd sites as the active center can promote the dissociation and activation of H2. The active hydrogen species dissociated on Pd active site migrate to the vicinity of the C=O bond to participate in hydrogenation to produce FA intermediates. Especially, the FA intermediates are further produced cyclic compounds at Lewis acid site by Piancatelli rearrangement mechanism [68–70]. In addition, the literatures have also reported that the presence of Brønsted acid sites can boost the protonation and dehydration of FA, which in turn promotes the formation of cyclic compounds [17]. As a typical 2D nanomaterial, the interlayer structure of HTs and the ability of anion-exchange cause directional regulation of the interlaminar microenvironment [39]. Therefore, we prepared Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 catalyst and Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalyst by ion exchange method of HNO3-NaNO3 mixed solution and formamide treatment, respectively. As can be seen from the XRD patterns in Fig. 2 and Table1, the (003) plane of Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 shifts to a small angle, and the interlayer space increases by 1.31 Å. The catalytic performance was further evaluated in FAL hydrogenative ring-arrangement reaction. As show in Fig. 7 a, the FFL conversion of 78.6 % and cyclic compound selectivity of 71.6 % are achieved over Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 catalyst. Meanwhile, the FFL conversion and cyclic compound selectivity are 82.1 % and 80.0 %, respectively. Compared with Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 catalyst, Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalyst enhances the selectivity of CPO by 10 %, and the selectivity of CPL decreased by 8 %. This result indicates that the interlayer anions and spaces have little effect on the activity and product selectivity at high conversion level in FFL hydrogenation reaction. However, a great effect is observed with respect to the intrinsic reaction rate in CPO hydrogenation to CPL. As shown in Fig. 7b, Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 catalyst with NO3 –-intercalation accelerates the specific reaction rate of the hydrogenation of CPO to CPL (CO3 2– vs NO3 –, 578 vs 1111 h–1). However, the specific reaction rate decreases over Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalyst (i.e., 408 h–1). This may be due to the different interactions between interlayer anions and HTs layers. The affinity of CO3 2– with the HTs layers is much higher than other anions (e.g., NO3 –), which makes it difficult for metals to enter the HTs interlayers, and allows the metals to be only appeared on the surface of HTs [56,71]. The specific interactions of Pd NPs and Co4Al1-HTs (CO3, NO3, NO3-EM) further lead to different dispersion degrees and chemical states of active Pd metal. In addition, it has been reported that the presence of interlayer NO3 – anion may allow Pd to enter the interlaminar structure of HTs, which can lead to difference in adsorption and activation of substrates [52,56]. Effect of solvent and hydrogen activation Solvents can be acted as reaction media, accelerate reaction rate, stabilize reaction intermediates, and participate in the mechanism in the catalytic reaction process [72–76]. Specifically, water exhibits various roles in the selective hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehydes with respect to affecting the solubility and mass transfer processes of reactants and products [77]. Water, as a highly polar solvent, improves the selectivity of unsaturated alcohols by promoting the polarization of C = O bonds [75]. For hydrogenation of FFL, the presence of water can promote the activation of FFL and opening of furan ring and it can also assist the proton transfer process [17]. To a certain extent, the performance, reaction mechanism and activation of hydrogen are closely related to the type, inherent properties, catalyst-solvent, solvent-solvent, reactant-solvent and other factors. Therefore, the role of a series of solvents in the Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalyzed FFL hydrogenation reaction has been further studied. As show in Fig. 8 , the polarity of the solvent has an important effect on the specific reaction rate of FFL hydrogenation. As listed in Table 3 , the polarity of the solvent decreases in the order of water > isopropanol ≈ EA>cyclohexane. The dielectric constant decreases in the order of water (ε = 80.1) > isopropanol (ε = 19.92) >EA (ε = 6.02) > cyclopentane (ε = 2.02). Therefore, water and isopropanol in these four solvents are polar proton solvents, EA belongs to polar aprotic solvents, and cyclohexane is a non-polar aprotic solvent. The specific reaction rate of Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalyzed FFL decreases with the decrease of solvent polarity. However, the specific reaction rate and the selectivity of cyclic compounds are reduced or even not generated in weak or non-polar solvents such as isopropanol, EA or cyclohexane, mainly due to the lower solubility of H2 in these solvents [78,79]. In water, Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalysts achieved a good specific reaction rate (538 h–1) and selectivity of cyclic compounds (77.5 %). This is consistent with previous literature reports that water as a solvent is one of the necessary conditions for FFL hydrogenation and ring-rearrangement [15–17,25–30]. By D2O labeling experiments, the direct participation of water can be confirmed in the Piancatelli rearrangement of the intermediate product FA in the reaction of FFL hydrogenation to CPO, mainly including the protonation and dehydration process of FA, and the nucleophilic rearrangement of furan ring opening caused by the nucleophilic of water molecule [23]. In addition, the dispersion of the catalyst in the different solvent is a non-negligible factor affecting the hydrogenation performance. The HTs material is rich in hydroxyl groups, and therefore, its strong hydrophilicity may regulate the dispersion of the catalyst in the solvent for affecting the catalytic activity. In our previous work of Pt-catalyzed the hydrogenation of FFL to FA, the hydrogen bond between solvent-reactant and solvent-catalyst can affect the catalytic performance [74]. Therefore, the catalytic effect of water would be worth further exploring in FFL hydrogenative rearrangement reaction. When the hydrogenation reaction operates in the metal-catalyzed unsaturated bond, the traditional catalytic mechanism believes that the hydrogen species produced by absorption and dissociation of H2 on the metal surface to reduce the unsaturated group of the adsorbed reactant molecule. Among metal catalysts, metal Pd is generally considered to have a strong ability to activate H2 [80,81]. Therefore, the H2-D2 exchange experiment was used at 80 °C, in which the flow rate ratio of H2, D2, and N2 was controlled to be 1:1:3 in a fixed-bed reactor device, and the intensity of the generated HD signal was recorded with online MS in Fig. 9 , Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalyst can activate and dissociate H2 for different interlayer anion of CO3 2–, NO3 –. However, the intensity of HD generation is 1.3–1.7 times that of CO3 2– intercalation after NO3 – anion exchange and formamide treatment. Therefore, it can be expected that the interlayer species of HTs facilitate the dissociation and activation of H2 [41]. The main reason may lie in the expansion of interlayer space of Co4Al1-HTs which increases the amount of interlayer water and NO3 – and enhance the Pd dispersion. On the one hand, [PdCl4]2– anions tend to enter the interlayer region of Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 and Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM support in the synthesis of catalysts [52,56]. On the other hand, due to the influence of molecular diffusion, it not only affects the reduction of [PdCl4]2– of interlayer anion, but also affects the ability of Pd to dissociate and activate H2. Therefore, metal Pd is used as the active site for adsorption, activation and dissociation of H2 in the Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalyzed FFL hydrogenation reaction, and the interlayer microenvironment has a certain influence on it. Recycling stability and structure stability of Pd-based catalysts The reusability of Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalyst was investigated in the recycling hydrogenation-rearrangement of FFL to CPO/CPL at 160 ℃ and 30 bar H2. After each hydrogenation reaction, the spent catalyst was separated by hot-filtered, washed by ethanol, dried at 70 ℃ for overnight before the recycling test. The stability results are shown in Fig. 10 a. Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 catalyst shows a relatively high FFL conversion of 83.7 % and the cyclic compound selectivity of 77.4 % in the first run. The FFL conversion of 77.3 % and the cyclic compound selectivity of 79.0 % are maintained after five runs. The activity reveals only a slight decrease in the five cycles, while the total selectivity of the ring rearrangement products is remained basically unchanged. The structure of the spent Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 catalyst after recycling test was characterized, and structural stability is demonstrated. The presence of Pd cannot be detected in the solution after the reaction using ICP-OES, indicating that there is no leaching of Pd into the reaction solution. The layer structure of Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 support is well remained as evidenced by the XRD pattern in Fig. 11 a. The XPS spectrum of Pd 3d illustrates that Pd maintains in the metallic Pd0 and Pd2+ states, as shown in Fig. 11b and Table 2. The area ratio of Pd2+/Pd0 is 23.4/76.7, implying that the active Pd species scarcely change after the five-reaction-run. The TEM images of the spent catalyst suggest that the Pd NPs still uniformly disperse on the surface of Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 support and possess a slightly grown NPs average size of 4.05±1.34 nm, as shown in Figs. 11c-d. The above characterization results demonstrate that the good reusability of Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 catalyst is benefited from its great structural preservation stability. In addition, the stability operation of the Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 and Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalysts were also supplemented in Fig. 10b–c. The results presented the selectivity of cyclic compounds remained 66–71 % and 77–79 %. respectively. However, the FFL conversion is gradually decreased during the four cycles. The FFL conversion is decreased from 78.6 % in the first operation to 65.1 % in the fourth cycle for Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 catalyst. The FFL conversion is decreased from 82.1 % to 75.5 % for Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalyst. The FT-IR spectrum was used to observe the change of interlayer anions, and the results are shown in Fig. S4. The peak at 1381 cm–1 is attributed to the vibration of NO3 – anions [82]. The peak at 1335 cm–1 belongs to the vibration of the bridge CO3 2– [83]. This indicates that the interlayer anions of Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3 and Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-NO3-EM catalysts are not stable during recycling tests. Some interlayer NO3 – anions can be converted into CO3 2– anions, mainly because the ability of NO3 – anions to form hydrogen bonds with hydroxyl groups or interlayer water molecules is much smaller than that of CO3 2– anions. Conclusions In summary, we report that the Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalyst prepared by NaBH4 one-step reduction method can efficiently catalyze the hydrogenative rearrangement of furfural to cyclic compounds. The Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 catalysts possess the catalytic performance with specific reaction rate of 538 h–1, and product selectivity of 77.5 % to cyclic compounds with water as reaction solvent at 160 ℃. The detailed characterization results of XRD, TEM, and XPS results reveal that Pd NPs are highly dispersed on the surface of Co4Al1-HTs with a mean size of 3.11±0.82 nm. This is ascribed to the synergistic interaction between metal Pd and Co4Al1-HTs support, and the abundant weak Lewis acid sites on the surface of the catalyst for promoting the formation of FFL hydrogenative rearrangement products. Interlayer anion exchange (CO3 2– and NO3 –) of Co4Al1-HTs changes the microenvironment of the support. The reaction result and H2-D2 exchange experiment was also further demonstrated the facilitation of these interlayer anions species in the process of the dissociation and activation of H2 and the conversion of FFL to cyclic compounds. Furthermore, the Pd/Co4Al1-HTs-CO3 catalyst presents satisfactory structural stability and catalytic stability against the cycling experiment. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of biomass-based compounds into highly value-added chemicals has received extensive attention in recent years. This work reports the liquid-phase selective hydrogenation and furan ring-rearrangement of furfural (FFL) into cyclopentanone (CPO) and cyclopentanol (CPL) over Pd/Co4Al1-HTs catalysts and water as the solvent. The specific reaction rate of the optimal catalyst at 160 °C reaches 538 h–1, and the selectivity of CPO/CPL is 77.5 %. By adopting the ion-exchange and formamide treatment methods, the type of the interlayer anions and interlayer spacing for the CoAl-HTs supports can be regulated, which can affect the state of the supported Pd sites and their catalytic activity and selectivity towards the ring-rearrangement products. Furthermore, the H2/D2 exchange experimental results demonstrate that the presence of the interlayer NO3 – anions of CoAl-HTs support promotes the activation and dissociation of H2, thereby accelerating the hydrogenation of FFL to cyclic compounds.
coredata.dc:title: Aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of biomass-derived furfural over Pd catalysts by tuning property of hydrotalcite support
